App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an omission—is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment that gives rise to liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences, not intent. While this case involves only an omission (failure to furnish heat) rather than affirmatively discussing affirmative acts versus omissions, in combination with Blackett it supports the broader proposition that the covenant covers serious interferences caused by both. The support is therefore indirect but consistent with the stated proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977)… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects any distinction between landlord malfeasance and nonfeasance where the landlord created the situation and had the right to control the objectionable conditions, and it grounds the constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment violation in what the landlord “did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.” That reasoning directly supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants against both affirmative acts and omissions by a landlord when those result in serious interference with use of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling… we decline to perpetuate that distinction between nonfeasance… and malfeasance…”

Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law implies a warranty of habitability in every residential lease, requiring that the premises remain fit for human occupation. *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion, not the majority, but even here Justice Quirico expressly agrees that, at least for dwelling units, Massachusetts should abandon caveat emptor and recognize an implied obligation tied to habitability standards, and he concurs in the actual disposition limiting rent to the reasonable value of defective premises. He criticizes the majority’s *formulation* of an “implied warranty of habitability” broader than the sanitary code, but not the basic concept that a landlord in a residential lease is under an implied, enforceable obligation to keep the premises fit for human occupation. Because this is not the controlling opinion and the excerpt is partial, confidence is medium rather than high.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability.
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the "percentage reduction approach" in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation. See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977). Although a detailed explanation of the trial judge’s calculations would have been preferable, an approximate dollar amount is permissible; damages in rent abatement cases generally are not capable of precise measurement.
